data.question: What is the title of the paper?
data.answer: A new sensitive structural motif inlaying the azides and tetrazole-based rigid 3D energetic MOFs: Highly sensitive primary explosives with excellent thermal stability

data.question: Who are the authors of the paper?
data.answer: Jian-Gang Xu, Yun-Fan Yan, Xiao-Zhen Li, Fa-Kun Zheng, and Guo-Cong Guo

data.question: What are the affiliations of the first author?
data.answer: College of Material Engineering, Fujian Agriculture and Forestry University, Fuzhou, Fujian 350108, P. R. China and State Key Laboratory of Structural Chemistry, Fujian Institute of Research on the Structure of Matter, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Fuzhou, Fujian 350002, P. R. China

data.question: What is the main focus of the study?
data.answer: The study focuses on employing the rigid tetrazole ligand to obtain two 3D energetic metal–organic frameworks (EMOFs) that exhibit decent thermostabilities and good energetic performance.

data.question: What are the names of the two 3D energetic metal–organic frameworks discussed in the study?
data.answer: [Cu(N3)(tz)]n 1 and [Cd3(N3)2(tz)3(OH)]n 2

data.question: What method was used to measure the thermal decomposition temperature (Tdec)?
data.answer: The DSC and TGA curves were used to measure the thermal decomposition temperature (Tdec).

data.question: Is compound 1 more sensitive than compound 2?
data.answer: Yes, compound 1 is more sensitive than compound 2.

data.question: Did the study reveal a new sensitive structural motif for primary explosives?
data.answer: Yes, the study revealed a new sensitive structural motif of strong repulsive steric clashes between the tetrazole ligand and azide ions for primary explosives.

data.question: What is the impact sensitivity (IS) value of compound 1?
data.answer: The impact sensitivity (IS) value of compound 1 is ≤ 1.0 J.

data.question: Does compound 1 possess the highest decomposition temperature among copper azide-based primary explosives?
data.answer: Yes, compound 1 possesses the highest decomposition temperature among copper azide-based primary explosives.

data.question: What are the electrostatic discharge sensitivity (ESD) values of compounds 1 and 2?
data.answer: The ESD of compound 1 is 92 mJ and compound 2 is >7500 mJ.

data.question: Was the complete combustion of compound 1 achieved during the oxygen bomb calorimetry test?
data.answer: No, the complete combustion of compound 1 was not achieved even spreading 10 mg among benzoic acid.

data.question: What is the heat of detonation (ΔHdet) value of compound 2?
data.answer: The heat of detonation (ΔHdet) value of compound 2 was calculated to be 3.71 kJ·g−1.

data.question: Are the mechanical sensitivities of compound 1 comparable with those of MOFT-CA?
data.answer: Yes, the mechanical sensitivities of compound 1 are comparable with those of MOFT-CA.

data.question: What does the study propose as a structural model for preparing highly sensitive primary explosives?
data.answer: The study proposes a structural model of the new sensitive structural motif inlaying the 3D EMOFs constructed by rigid and cheated ligand to prepare highly sensitive primary explosives.

data.question: What is the role of the tetrazole ligand in the study's EMOFs?
data.answer: The tetrazole ligand, possessing high nitrogen content and chelated coordination nodes, is employed to prepare two tightly packed 3D rigid metal–organic frameworks.

data.question: Did the study find that compound 1 can be stored stably under normal conditions?
data.answer: Yes, the study found that compound 1 can be stored stably under normal conditions.

data.question: What is the significance of the study's findings on the sensitive structural motif?
data.answer: The study's findings on the sensitive structural motif provide guidance to design and synthesize advanced primary explosives with desirable attributes.

data.question: Is compound 2 considered to be an extremely sensitive explosive?
data.answer: No, compound 2 is considered to be a very sensitive explosive, not extremely sensitive.

data.question: What does the study conclude about the energetic properties of compounds 1 and 2?
data.answer: The study concludes that compounds 1 and 2 exhibit good thermal stabilities, suitable sensitivities, and excellent detonation performances.
